awd_titl_txt: Diversifying CS with a Biology-themed Introductory CS Course at a Large, Diverse Public University
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create an introductory Computer Science course with a Biology theme, by adapting and modifying an existing course developed at a small private college, for use at the University of Illinois at Chicago.  The goal of the project is to attract more women to computer science and enable biology students to use the power of computing and computational thinking.  Implementing this course at a large scale, in a different academic setting, will result in a version of the course that will be more widely adoptable.  A robust dissemination plan will raise awareness of the work, and will result in broader adoption of the course at a national level.

The research component of this project will make significant contributions to the knowledge base about what attracts women and under-represented groups to computing and whether or not the results that were obtained when this course was taught in a small college setting can be replicated at a large public institution.  The project will measure student attitudes and capabilities in computing using a variety of methods including the Computer Science Attitudes Survey.  The result will be a measure of student confidence learning computer science, their attitude toward success in computer science, their view of computer science as a male domain, their view of the usefulness of computer science, and their motivation in computer science

por.por_cntn:
We created a version of a first college course in computer science ("CS 1") that has a strong biology theme and have now offered it at University of Illinois Chicago (UIC) several times. It has recently been given its own course number and is cross listed in both the Computer Science and Biological Sciences departments. In Computer Science, the course is one of several choices for the first introductory course for computer science majors and minors. In Biological Sciences, the course is an elective that provides course credit towards the major.

We have measured how successful the course has been and published our results in the computer science education literature. We have also made the entirety of the course materials freely available for instructors at any other institution to use. 

Three key goals of this course were:

  • To allow biology students to obtain expertise in using the power of computing as software builders, not merely as tool users. Also, to allow computer science students to see important biological uses for their computer science work.
  • To simultaneously provide a full education in CS 1. To meet this goal, it was important that this course do as good a job of educating students in computer science as a standard first course in computer science.
  • To draw more women into the study of computer science. Women are severely underrepresented in computer science, whereas women make up somewhat over half of biology majors nationwide.

What is meant by "strong biology theme" is that almost all the examples presented in the class, and almost all the homework assignments, are drawn from biology. For example, in all offerings of the course, students have done extensive work in manipulating strings of letters that represent DNA and determining what proteins that DNA encodes. In some offerings of the course, students learned about the data structures called trees by working with representations of the Tree of Life, which shows how various species have evolved. Starting with the Spring 2020 offering of the course, we introduced assignments that model the spread of infectious diseases and vaccine design, in general, and provide some understanding of the SARS-CoV-2, in particular.

What is meant by "first college course in computer science" is that the course includes all the learning outcomes found in a typical CS 1 course for computer science minors and majors at any US college or university. Some of the key learning outcomes in all such courses include:

  • The big ideas of computer science, often summarized as computational thinking.
  • How to design, write, and debug medium-small computer programs in some programming language. For our course, we used Python, which is the most used programming language for CS 1 courses around the country today.
  • Some of the underlying knowledge about topics such as where data is stored in a computer's memory for a particular programming language construct that differentiate expert computer programmers from novices.

We measured student outcomes and knowledge in this course and in a standard CS 1 course being offered at UIC during at the same time during several different semesters. We found that students were roughly equally successful in obtaining the key computer science learning outcomes across the two classes. This was a good outcome, because instructors have to spend some time in the biology themed course providing instruction on biology topics. (This course has no biology prerequisite.)

During the funded period of the grant, the biology themed CS 1 course did not attract significantly more women than the standard course. However, in Fall of 2021, immediately after the end of the funding period, the biology themed course does have significantly more women enrolled in it than the standard course. We speculate that the course had to both be given its own course number, and cross listed in Biological Sciences, and generally to be around for a while and become known among students before it could start attracting women whose primary interest is biology. We further speculate that the course will continue to attract significantly more women than men going forward.

 


Last Modified: 10/25/2021
Modified by: Robert H Sloan
